item.title: Thursday, February 22, 2024
item.description:
#

I've been neglecting Tinderbox this week, which is a mistake since I'm participating in the Blogging with Tinderbox meetup on Saturday. I'll be leaning on Dave for the meat of the thing, since he's been putting a lot of thought into the topic recently. I've gotten this Tinderbox file to the point where I don't need to think about it much, so I haven't. My thoughts have been more around which tool to use for blogging, which sometimes means Tinderbox and sometimes doesn't. Should be interesting.

item.title: Monday, February 19, 2024
item.description:
#

I used to love databases. I put everything in them. I've used SQL Server, Postgres, Oracle, Access, MySQL, etc. Loved them. But now, for some reason, I avoid them and I'm not sure why. Maybe it's because of my infatuation with plain text and associated tooling. Maybe it's fear of "lock-in". Just an observation. I wonder how limiting this is in what I decide to build.

#

Just for fun, I recently put up a sort of landing page at jackbaty.com. It's just an org-mode file exported as HTML with the most basic CSS I could muster that also makes the page readable. I plan to keep a page like this around, but I'm thinking about moving it from jackbaty.com to jack.baty.net. I've been slowly moving from a bunch of custom domains to putting everything under subdomains of baty.net. I need at least one totally static site under which I can drop documents and files that isn't controlled by a CMS of any kind. I have static.baty.net now, so maybe some version of that would work? Still noodling on it.

#

Server issues this morning have put me in a "No, you host it!" mood. Some days I love tinkering with servers and deployment scripts and such. Other days (today, for example) I never want to touch a server again.

item.title: Sunday, February 18, 2024
item.description:
#

I recently wrote about my upcoming Flickr subscription and whether I would renew after 20 years. I find Glass.photo to be a better visual experience and the conversations there are more frequent and of higher quality. But really they are two different things for me. Glass is where I showcase my photography and Flickr is where I share my photos. The difference is subtle, but meaningful, which is why I'll probably keep both. I'm reminded of PetaPixel's recent post: 10 Reasons Why Flickr is the Best Site on the Internet for Photographers.

#

Why do I feel an obligation to software? There are apps that I've used for quite a long time and for some reason I feel obligated to continue using them. Tinderbox, TiddlyWiki, and Emacs are good examples. They're all great, but I rarely need the power afforded me and it's not always worth the added complexity. But I tinker, you know. They are part of my muscle memory. I have many (many!) documents that I created using each of them. I suspect that maybe I feel this way because they're also part of my identity. I've written about them often. I could simply stop using any of them and who would care? No one, probably, but since I can't seem to shut up about anything I would still feel guilty, somehow.

#

I could easily (easily!) run my life using a paper notebook and perhaps a few index cards. Days like today I think about doing just that. Maybe I will.

#

I'm still not working, meaning I have a lot of time my hands. Having so much time offers me the opportunity to sit and stare at things and over-think everything about them. Where should I document the fact that I upgraded Sonoma on the MBP to 14.3.1 this morning? The correct answer is, "Who gives a shit?!". Spending hours and hours figuring out how and where to document all the minutiae in my life is an unnecessary and life-wasting routine. I need to go out and do interesting and meaningful things so that I no longer have the time nor inclination to document everything all the time.

item.title: Saturday, February 17, 2024
item.description:
#

It bothers me a little that moving the content here to any other platform would be a large project that I don't want to ever have to tackle. It limits my enjoyment of using Tinderbox for blogging. But it sure is fun while I'm here, so why do I trouble myself by thinking about moving stuff?

(Yet) another reason I use Tinderbox

Dave Rogers writes about a small update to Tinderbox made recently based on a conversation during a short video call between himself, me, Mark Bernstein (Tinderbox's author), and Michael Becker. Dave and I both mentioned small nits we had to pick with one of Tinderbox's tools. I even said that it was only a minor inconvenience and I felt like I was whining by even mentioning it. And yet, several days later, a new Tinderbox beta arrived with improvements solving both of our issues. I've been talking about Eastgate's exceptional support and responsiveness since at least 2007 and it remains one reason why Tinderbox is worth every penny.

item.title: Wednesday, February 14, 2024
item.description:
#

I've never been into anything hard enough to argue over what might be canon or not.

#

I like too many things. For example, I like Tinderbox and Emacs equally for keeping a Daybook. It's maddening to try and choose just one.

Tinderbox note icons

One of Tinderbox's many little unsung features are the small note icons that appear next to each note.

They pack a ton of useful info into a tiny space. They show whether a note contains text, how much, and if there are inbound or outbound links. They also "yellow" with age, so I can see at a glance which are new and which are old. It's subtle, clever, and very useful.

item.title: Tuesday, February 13, 2024
item.description:
#

I am sitting on the fence between plain text and GUI-licious tools. I'm typing this in Tinderbox and spending lots of time in my Daybook.tbx file. I've reacquainted myself with OmniFocus and have even fired up the new version of Curio. On the other hand, I remain deep into Emacs, but have also been using Mutt for email and Taskwarrior for tasks and now I'm infatuated with nb. So you can see my dilemma. I love so many things about all of them that I never want to give any of them up completely. So I continue to scatter my stuff among a dozen apps and end up frustrated. I'm still having fun, though, so I guess it's worth it?

#

When I like something, I tend to say, "It's really good!" but when I don't like something I try to say, "I didn't care for it." rather than "It's terrible!" So, I treat positive things as objective and negative things as subjective. I think that's ok.
